<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">We do
    not currently intend to hold an annual meeting of stockholders
    until after our consummation of a business
    transaction.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    We do not currently intend to hold an annual meeting of
    stockholders until after we consummate the business transaction,
    and thus may not be in compliance with Section&#160;211(b) of
    the DGCL, which requires an annual meeting of stockholders be
    held for the purposes of electing directors in accordance with a
    company&#146;s bylaws unless such election is made by written
    consent in lieu of such a meeting. Therefore, if our
    stockholders want us to hold an annual meeting prior to our
    consummation of a business transaction, they may attempt to
    force us to hold one by submitting an application to the
    Delaware Court of Chancery in accordance with
    Section&#160;211(c) of the DGCL.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Risks
    Related to Crumbs&#146; Business and Industry</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <I>You should carefully consider the following risk factors,
    together with all of the other information included in this
    Offer to Purchase, before you decide whether to tender
    Securities in the Offer. As 57th Street&#146;s operations will
    be those of Crumbs upon the consummation of the Transaction, a
    number of the following risk factors relate to the business and
    operations of Crumbs and 57th&#160;Street, as the successor to
    such business.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">If
    Crumbs is unable to achieve its rapid growth strategy, its
    business could be materially adversely affected.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs&#146; growth strategy depends on its ability to open new
    stores on a timely and profitable basis. Crumbs has experienced
    delays in store openings from time to time. Crumbs may
    experience delays in the future and Crumbs cannot assure you
    that it will be able to achieve its expansion goals. Any
    inability to implement Crumbs&#146; growth strategy could
    materially adversely affect its business, financial condition,
    operating results or cash flows. Crumbs&#146; ability to expand
    successfully will depend on a number of factors, some of which
    are beyond its control, including:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    identification and availability of suitable store sites;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    competition for prime real estate sites;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    negotiation of favorable leases;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    management of construction and development costs of new stores;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    securing required governmental approvals and permits;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    recruitment of qualified operating personnel;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the availability of, and Crumbs&#146; ability to obtain,
    adequate suppliers of ingredients that meet its quality
    standards;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the impact of inclement weather, natural disasters and other
    calamities;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    competition in new and existing markets;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    general economic conditions.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Any
    inability to manage Crumbs&#146; growth effectively could
    materially adversely affect its operating results and result in
    future results that are unpredictable.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs has grown significantly since its inception and intends
    to continue its expansion. Crumbs&#146; existing store
    management systems, financial and management controls and
    information systems may not be adequate to support its planned
    expansion. Crumbs&#146; ability to manage its growth effectively
    will require it to continue to enhance these systems, procedures
    and controls and to locate, hire, train and retain operating
    personnel.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Additionally, Crumbs&#146; growth strategy and the substantial
    investment associated with the development of each new store may
    cause Crumbs&#146; operating results to fluctuate and be
    unpredictable or adversely affect its
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    18
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    profits. Crumbs cannot assure you that it will be able to
    respond on a timely basis to all of the changing demands that
    its planned expansion will impose on management and on its
    existing infrastructure. If Crumbs is unable to manage its
    growth effectively, its business and operating results could be
    materially adversely impacted and its future results will be
    unpredictable.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    expansion into new markets may present increased risks due to
    its unfamiliarity with those areas.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Some of Crumbs&#146; new stores are planned for markets where it
    has little or no operating experience. Those markets may have
    different competitive conditions, consumer tastes and
    discretionary spending patterns than its existing markets.
    Consumers in a new market may not be familiar with the Crumbs
    brand, and Crumbs may need to build brand awareness in such
    market through greater investments in advertising and
    promotional activity than it originally planned. Crumbs may find
    it more difficult in new markets to hire, motivate and keep
    qualified employees who can project its vision. Stores opened in
    new markets may also have lower average store revenue than
    stores opened in existing markets, and may have higher
    construction, occupancy or operating costs than stores in
    existing markets. Further, Crumbs may have difficulty in finding
    reliable commercial bakers, suppliers or distributors that can
    provide it, either initially or over time, with adequate
    supplies of ingredients meeting its quality standards. Revenue
    at stores opened in new markets may not reach expected revenue
    and profit levels, negatively impacting overall profitability.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">You
    should not rely on average store sales experienced by Crumbs in
    the past because they may not be indicative of future
    results.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs&#146; average store sales may not continue at the rates
    achieved over the past several years. A number of factors have
    historically affected, and may affect Crumbs&#146; average store
    sales in the future, including:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    introduction of new menu items;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    initial sales performance by new stores;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    competition;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    consumer trends;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Crumbs&#146; ability to execute its business strategy
    effectively;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    general regional and national economic conditions.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Changes in Crumbs&#146; average store sales or Crumbs&#146;
    inability to increase its average units sales could cause its
    operating results to vary adversely from expectations, which
    could adversely affect its results of operations. Changes in
    Crumbs&#146; average sales results may not meet the expectations
    of analysts or investors which could cause the price of the
    combined company&#146;s common stock after consummation of the
    Transaction to fluctuate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    has a limited operating history and Crumbs may be unable to
    achieve and sustain profitability.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    The first Crumbs store was opened in 2003. As of
    January&#160;19, 2011, Crumbs was operating 34 stores, nine of
    which have been open for less than one year. Accordingly, you
    have limited information with which to evaluate Crumbs&#146;
    business and prospects. As a result, forecasts of Crumbs&#146;
    future revenues, expenses and operating results may not be as
    accurate as they would be if Crumbs had a longer history of
    operations. Crumbs intends to continue to expend significant
    financial and management resources on the development of
    additional stores. Crumbs cannot predict whether it will be able
    to achieve or sustain revenue growth, profitability or positive
    cash flow in the future. See &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion
    and Analysis of Financial Conditions and Results of Operations
    of Crumbs&#148; and the financial statements included in this
    Offer to Purchase for information on the history of Crumbs&#146;
    losses.
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    19
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    revenue and profit growth could be adversely affected if
    comparable store revenue is less than expected.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    While future revenue growth will depend substantially on
    Crumbs&#146; plans for new store openings, the level of
    comparable store revenue will also affect its revenue growth and
    will continue to be an important factor affecting profit growth.
    This is because the profit margin on comparable store revenue is
    generally higher than the profit margin on new store openings,
    as comparable store revenue enable fixed costs to be spread over
    a higher revenue base. Crumbs may not achieve comparable store
    revenue growth or that the change in comparable store revenue
    could be negative. If this were to happen, revenue and profit
    growth would be adversely affected.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    store expansion strategy includes further penetration of
    existing markets. This strategy can cause sales in some of
    Crumbs&#146; existing stores to decline, which could result in
    store closures.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    In accordance with Crumbs&#146; expansion strategy, Crumbs
    intends to open new stores, including in Crumbs&#146; existing
    markets. Since Crumbs&#146; customers typically represent
    customers from a relatively small radius around each of its
    stores, the sales performance and customer counts for stores
    near the area in which a new store opens may decline due to
    cannibalization or competition between its closely-situated
    stores, which could result in store closures.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    stores are currently concentrated in the Northeast and the West
    Coast regions of the United&#160;States, particularly in the New
    York City area and the Los Angeles area. Accordingly, Crumbs is
    highly vulnerable to negative occurrences in these
    regions.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs currently operates 24 stores in the Northeast, of which
    14 are located in the New York City area, and six stores in
    California, all of which are located in or around the Los
    Angeles area. As a result, Crumbs is particularly susceptible to
    adverse trends and economic conditions in these areas. In
    addition, given Crumbs&#146; geographic concentration, negative
    publicity regarding any of its stores could have a material
    adverse effect on its business and operations, as could other
    regional factors impacting the local economies in these markets.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    is subject to all of the risks associated with leasing space
    subject to long-term non-cancelable leases and with respect to
    the real property that it may own in the future.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs competes for real estate and Crumbs&#146; inability to
    secure real estate in desirable locations or on favorable lease
    terms could impact Crumbs&#146; ability to grow. Crumbs&#146;
    leases generally have initial terms of between 10 and
    15&#160;years, and generally can be extended in up to five-year
    increments (at increased rates) if at all. Additionally, in
    certain instances, there may be change in control provisions in
    the lease which put Crumbs in a competitive disadvantage when
    negotiating extensions or which require Crumbs to get landlord
    consent for certain transactions including, in some cases, the
    proposed business transaction. All of its leases require a fixed
    annual rent, although some require the payment of additional
    rent if store revenue exceeds a negotiated amount. Crumbs&#146;
    leases include &#147;net&#148; leases, which require it to pay
    all of the cost of insurance, taxes, maintenance and utilities.
    Crumbs generally cannot cancel these leases. Additional sites
    that Crumbs may lease are likely to be subject to similar
    long-term non-cancelable leases. If an existing or future store
    is not profitable, and Crumbs decides to close a particular
    store, it may nonetheless be committed to perform its
    obligations under the applicable lease including, among other
    things, paying the base rent for the balance of the lease term.
    In addition, as each of its leases expires, Crumbs may fail to
    negotiate renewals, either on commercially acceptable terms or
    at all, which could cause it to close stores in desirable
    locations. Current locations of Crumbs&#146; stores may become
    unattractive as demographic patterns change.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    may face difficulties entering into new or modified arrangements
    with existing or new suppliers or new service
    providers.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    As Crumbs expands its operations, it may have to seek new
    commercial bakers, suppliers and service providers or enter into
    new arrangements with existing ones, and it may encounter
    difficulties or be unable to negotiate pricing or other terms as
    favorable as those it currently enjoys, which could harm its
    business and
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    20
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    operating results. However, because Crumbs currently has not
    begun to negotiate new or amended contracts with suppliers and
    service providers, it cannot now quantify with any certainty
    potential increases in its expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    may not be able to adequately protect its intellectual property,
    which could harm the value of its brand and adversely affect its
    business.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs&#146; intellectual property is material to the conduct of
    its business. Crumbs&#146; ability to implement its business
    plan successfully depends in part on its ability to build
    further brand recognition using its trademarks, service marks
    and other proprietary intellectual property, including its name
    and logos. Crumbs has registered its trademarks in the United
    States, the European Community and Japan; however, if
    Crumbs&#146; efforts to protect its intellectual property are
    inadequate, or if any third party misappropriates or infringes
    on its intellectual property, the value of its brands may be
    harmed, which could have a material adverse effect on its
    business and might prevent its brands from achieving or
    maintaining market acceptance. While Crumbs has not encountered
    claims from prior users of intellectual property relating to its
    bake shop operations in areas where it operates or intends to
    conduct operations, there can be no assurances that it will not
    encounter such claims. If so, this could harm Crumbs&#146;
    image, brand or competitive position and cause it to incur
    significant penalties and costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Disruptions
    in Crumbs&#146; supply chain and the inability to predict demand
    could adversely affect its profitability and operating
    results.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs depends on deliveries exclusively from its regional
    suppliers of baked goods and other products daily. Accordingly,
    Crumbs is particularly susceptible to supply volatility as a
    result of adverse weather and traffic conditions and potential
    mechanical issues related to the delivery trucks of Crumbs&#146;
    suppliers. Crumbs&#146; dependence on frequent deliveries to its
    stores by single regional distributors could cause shortages or
    supply interruptions that could adversely impact its operations.
    Additionally, because none of the Crumbs retail stores bake the
    baked goods they sell, each Crumbs store is required to estimate
    and order suitable inventory for each day. If stores are unable
    to substantially predict the demand, Crumbs&#146; profitability
    and operating results may be adversely effected. There are many
    factors which could cause shortages or interruptions in the
    supply of Crumbs&#146; products, including weather,
    unanticipated demand, labor, production or distribution
    problems, quality issues and cost, and the financial health of
    Crumbs&#146; suppliers, most of which are beyond Crumbs&#146;
    control, and which could have an adverse effect on Crumbs&#146;
    business and results of operations.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    results may fluctuate and could fall below expectations of
    securities analysts and investors due to seasonality and other
    factors, resulting in a decline in the combined company&#146;s
    stock price after consummation of the business
    transaction.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs&#146; quarterly and yearly results have varied in the
    past, and Crumbs believes that its quarterly operating results
    will vary in the future. Factors such as unseasonably cold or
    wet weather conditions, labor availability and wages of store
    management and employee, infrastructure costs, changes in
    consumer preferences and discretionary spending, general
    economic conditions, commodity, energy, insurance or other
    operating costs may cause Crumbs&#146; quarterly results to
    fluctuate. For this reason, results for any one quarter are not
    necessarily indicative of results to be expected for any other
    quarter or for any year. You should not rely upon Crumbs&#146;
    historical quarterly operating results as indications of future
    performance.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    may need additional capital in the future and it may not be
    available on acceptable terms.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    The development of Crumbs&#146; business may require significant
    additional capital in the future to, among other things, fund
    its operations, expand the range of services Crumbs offers and
    finance future acquisitions and investments. To meet its capital
    needs, Crumbs expects to rely on its cash flow from operations
    and cash generated from the proposed business transaction with
    57th Street. There can be no assurance, however, that these
    sources of financing, or alternative sources will be available
    on terms favorable to Crumbs, or at all. Crumbs&#146; ability to
    obtain additional financing will be subject to a number of
    factors, including market conditions, its operating performance
    and investor sentiment. These factors may make the timing,
    amount,
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    21
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    terms and conditions or additional financings unattractive to
    Crumbs. If Crumbs is unable to raise additional capital, its
    growth and its business could be impeded.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    success depends substantially upon the continued retention of
    certain key personnel.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs believes that its success has been dependent and
    continues to be dependent to a significant extent on the efforts
    and abilities of its senior management team. The members of its
    management team currently are employed on an &#147;at-will&#148;
    basis and may resign from employment at any time. In connection
    with the proposed business transaction, Jason Bauer, Mia Bauer
    and John Ireland will enter into employment agreements with 57th
    Street at the Closing. Crumbs&#146; failure to retain any of
    these individuals could adversely affect its ability to build on
    the efforts they have undertaken with respect to the Crumbs
    business. These individuals may be unfamiliar with the
    requirements of operating a public company as well as United
    States securities laws, which could cause the combined company
    to have to expend time and resources in helping them become
    familiar with such laws.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    will incur increased costs as a result of being a subsidiary of
    a public company.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    As a subsidiary of a public company, Crumbs will incur
    significant legal, accounting and other expenses that it did not
    incur as a private company. The U.S.&#160;Sarbanes-Oxley Act of
    2002, Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
    of 2010 and related rules of the SEC, regulate corporate
    governance practices of public companies. Crumbs expects that
    compliance with these public company requirements will increase
    its costs and make some activities more time-consuming. For
    example, Crumbs will create new board committees and adopt new
    internal controls and disclosure controls and procedures. In
    addition, Crumbs will incur additional expenses associated with
    its SEC reporting requirements. A number of those requirements
    will require Crumbs to carry out activities it has not done
    previously. For example, in the future it is likely that under
    Section&#160;404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, Crumbs will need to
    document and test its internal control procedures, its
    management will need to assess and report on Crumbs&#146;
    internal control over financial reporting and its independent
    accountants will need to issue an opinion on that assessment and
    the effectiveness of those controls. Furthermore, if Crumbs
    identifies any issues in complying with those requirements (for
    example, if Crumbs or its accountants identified a material
    weakness or significant deficiency in Crumbs&#146; internal
    control over financial reporting), Crumbs could incur additional
    costs rectifying those issues, and the existence of those issues
    could adversely affect Crumbs&#146; reputation or investor
    perceptions of Crumbs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    The terms of the director and officer liability insurance
    maintained by Crumbs following the closing may not be sufficient
    to attract and retain directors. As a result, it may be more
    difficult for Crumbs to attract and retain qualified persons to
    serve on its board of directors or as executive officers.
    Advocacy efforts by stockholders and third parties may also
    prompt even more changes in governance and reporting
    requirements. Crumbs cannot predict or estimate the amount of
    additional costs Crumbs may incur or the timing of such costs.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    business is affected by changes in consumer preferences and
    discretionary spending.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs&#146; success depends, in part, upon the popularity of
    its food products and its ability to develop new menu items that
    appeal to consumers. Shifts in consumer preferences away from
    Crumbs&#146; stores or its menu items, Crumbs&#146; inability to
    develop new menu items that appeal to consumers, or changes in
    Crumbs&#146; menu that eliminate items popular with some
    consumers could harm its business. Also, Crumbs&#146; success
    depends to a significant extent on discretionary consumer
    spending, which is influenced by general economic conditions and
    the availability of discretionary income. Accordingly, Crumbs
    may experience declines in sales during economic downturns or
    during periods of uncertainty. Any material decline in the
    amount of discretionary spending could have a material adverse
    effect on Crumbs&#146; sales, results of operations, business
    and financial condition.
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    22
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    success depends on its ability to compete with cupcake specific
    bakeries, traditional bakeries and other food service
    businesses.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    The industry in which Crumbs operates is intensely competitive
    and Crumbs competes with many well-established traditional
    bakeries, cupcake-specific bakeries and other companies
    providing baked goods and coffee, on the basis of taste, quality
    and price of products offered, customer service, atmosphere,
    location, convenience and overall customer experience. Crumbs
    also competes with certain quick-services restaurants,
    delicatessens, caf&#233;s, take-out food service companies,
    supermarkets and convenience stores that offer the same types of
    baked goods. Aggressive discounts by Crumbs&#146; competitors or
    the entrance of new competitors into Crumbs&#146; markets could
    reduce its sales and profit margins. Crumbs also competes with
    these competitors for desirable locations and some of its
    competitors may have capital resources greater than Crumbs&#146;
    as discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Many of Crumbs&#146; competitors or potential competitors have
    substantially greater financial and other resources than Crumbs
    does, which may allow them to react to changes in pricing,
    marketing and the bakery industry better than Crumbs can. As
    Crumbs&#146; competitors expand their operations, Crumbs expects
    competition to intensify. In addition, other new or established
    companies may develop baked goods stores that operate with
    concepts similar to Crumbs&#146;, including the sale of gourmet
    cupcakes. Competition also could cause Crumbs to modify or
    evolve its products, designs or strategies. If Crumbs does so,
    Crumbs cannot guarantee that it will be successful in
    implementing the changes or that Crumbs&#146; profitability will
    not be negatively impacted by them.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs also competes with other employers in its markets for
    hourly workers and may be subject to higher labor costs. If
    Crumbs is unable to successfully compete in its markets, Crumbs
    may be unable to sustain or increase its revenues and
    profitability.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    is dependent upon a small number of exclusive commercial bakers
    and other suppliers for a significant amount of its menu items.
    The loss of any supplier could adversely affect Crumbs&#146;
    operating results.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs relies on four primary commercial bakery suppliers for
    its baked goods products and one primary vendor for its paper
    goods and packaging. As of January&#160;19, 2011, Crumbs had
    agreements with four regional bakery suppliers. Crumbs has
    signed three-year exclusive production agreements (with
    automatic one-year renewals) with each of its four regional
    suppliers. Crumbs&#146; regional suppliers are for the New York,
    Los Angeles, Chicago and Washington,&#160;D.C. area markets.
    Crumbs&#146; exclusive dependence on daily deliveries from only
    four regional suppliers could cause shortages or supply
    interruptions that could adversely impact Crumbs&#146;
    operations. Any increase in distribution prices or failure by
    Crumbs&#146; distributors to perform could adversely affect
    Crumbs&#146; operating results.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    industry is affected by litigation and publicity concerning food
    quality, health and other issues, which can cause customers to
    avoid Crumbs&#146; products and result in
    liabilities.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Food service businesses, such as bakeries, can be adversely
    affected by litigation and complaints from customers or
    government authorities resulting from food quality, illness,
    injury or other health concerns or operating issues stemming
    from one store or a limited number of stores. Adverse publicity
    about these allegations may negatively affect Crumbs, regardless
    of whether the allegations are true, by discouraging customers
    from buying Crumbs&#146; products. Crumbs could also incur
    significant liabilities if a lawsuit or claim results in a
    decision against Crumbs or litigation costs regardless of the
    result.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs&#146;
    business could be adversely affected by increased labor costs or
    labor shortages.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Labor is a primary component in the cost of operating
    Crumbs&#146; business. Crumbs devotes significant resources to
    recruiting and training its managers and hourly employees.
    Increased labor costs due to competition, increased minimum wage
    or employee benefits costs or otherwise, would adversely impact
    Crumbs&#146; operating expenses. In addition, Crumbs&#146;
    success depends on its ability to attract, motivate and retain
    qualified employees, including store managers and staff, to keep
    pace with Crumbs&#146; growth strategy. If
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    23
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs is unable to attract, motivate and retain qualified
    employees, its results of operations may be adversely affected.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Fluctuations
    in various food and supply costs, including dairy, could
    adversely affect Crumbs&#146; operating results.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    The prices of butter, flour, milk and eggs, which are the main
    ingredients in Crumbs&#146; baked goods, and coffee may
    fluctuate. Supplies and prices of the various products that are
    used to prepare Crumbs&#146; baked goods can be affected by a
    variety of factors, such as weather, seasonal fluctuations,
    demand, politics and economics in the producing countries. An
    increase in pricing of any ingredient that is used in
    Crumbs&#146; baked goods could result in an adjustment to the
    compensation due to suppliers and may have an adverse effect on
    Crumbs&#146; operating results and profitability.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    could be party to litigation that could adversely affect it by
    distracting management, increasing its expenses or subjecting it
    to material money damages and other remedies.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs may be subject to the filing of complaints or lawsuits
    against it alleging that it is responsible for some illness or
    injury suffered at or after a visit to its stores, or alleging
    that Crumbs has problems with food quality or operations. Crumbs
    is also subject to a variety of other claims arising in the
    ordinary course of its business, including personal injury
    claims, contract claims and claims alleging violations of
    federal and state law regarding workplace and employment
    matters, discrimination and similar matters, and it could become
    subject to class action or other lawsuits related to these or
    different matters in the future. Claims may be expensive to
    defend and may divert time and money away from Crumbs&#146;
    operations and hurt its performance. A judgment in excess of
    Crumbs&#146; insurance coverage or our insurance carriers&#146;
    decision to deny or limit insurance coverage for any claims
    could materially and adversely affect Crumbs&#146; financial
    condition or results of operations. Any adverse publicity
    resulting from these allegations may also materially and
    adversely affect Crumbs&#146; reputation or prospects, which in
    turn could adversely affect its results of operation and
    profitability.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">If
    Crumbs fails to comply with governmental laws or regulations or
    if these laws or regulations change, its business could
    suffer.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    In connection with the operation of Crumbs&#146; business, it is
    subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws and
    regulations, including those related to:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    building construction and zoning requirements;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    nutritional content labeling and disclosure requirements;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    management and protection of the personal data of Crumbs&#146;
    employees and customers;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    environmental matters;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    sales tax.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs&#146; stores are licensed and subject to regulation under
    federal, state and local laws, including business, health, fire
    and safety codes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Various federal and state labor laws govern Crumbs&#146;
    operations and its relationship with its associates, including
    minimum wage, overtime, accommodation and working conditions,
    benefits, citizenship requirements, insurance matters,
    workers&#146; compensation, disability laws such as the Federal
    Americans with Disabilities Act, child labor laws and
    anti-discrimination laws.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    These labor laws are complex and vary from location to location,
    which complicates monitoring and compliance. As a result,
    regulatory risks are inherent in Crumbs&#146; operations. Crumbs
    may experience material difficulties or failures with respect to
    compliance with these labor laws in the future. Crumbs&#146;
    failure to comply with these labor laws could result in required
    renovations to its facilities, litigation, fines, penalties,
    judgments or other sanctions including the temporary suspension
    of the operation of Crumbs&#146; stores or a delay
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    24
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    in construction or opening of stores, any of which could
    adversely affect Crumbs&#146; business, operations and
    reputation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    In recent years, there has been an increased legislative,
    regulatory and consumer focus at the federal, state and
    municipal levels on the food industry, including nutrition and
    advertising practices. For example, several states and
    individual municipalities, including New York City and the state
    of California, have adopted regulations requiring that certain
    restaurants include caloric or other nutritional information on
    their menu boards and on printed menus, which must be plainly
    visible to consumers at the point of ordering. Likewise, there
    have been several similar proposals on the national level. As a
    result, Crumbs may in the future become subject to other
    regulations in the area of nutrition disclosure or advertising,
    such as requirements to provide information about the
    nutritional content of Crumbs&#146; food, which could increase
    its expenses or slow customer flow.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">The
    continuing adverse economic conditions could adversely affect
    Crumbs&#146; business and financial results and have a material
    adverse effect on its liquidity and capital
    resources.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    As widely reported, the U.S.&#160;economy continues to
    experience adverse economic conditions and uncertainty about
    economic stability. While there are signs that conditions may be
    improving, there is no certainty that this trend will continue
    or that credit and financial markets and confidence in economic
    conditions will not deteriorate again. Crumbs&#146; customers
    may make fewer discretionary purchases as a result of job
    losses, foreclosures, bankruptcies, reduced access to credit and
    falling home prices. Because a key point in Crumbs&#146;
    business strategy is maintaining its transaction count and
    margin growth, any significant decrease in customer traffic or
    average profit per transaction will negatively impact
    Crumbs&#146; financial performance as reduced revenues create
    downward pressure on margins. Financial difficulties experienced
    by Crumbs&#146; suppliers could result in product delays or
    shortages. Additionally, it is unknown when the broader national
    economy will fully recover. An economy that continues to
    deteriorate or fails to improve could have a material adverse
    effect on Crumbs&#146; liquidity and capital resources,
    including its ability to raise additional capital if needed, the
    ability of Southeastern Bank to honor draws on Crumbs&#146;
    standby letters of credit, or otherwise negatively impact
    Crumbs&#146; business and financial results.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Crumbs
    may also incur costs resulting from other security risks it may
    face in connection with its electronic processing and
    transmission of confidential customer information.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Crumbs uses commercially available software and other
    technologies to provide security for processing and transmission
    of customer credit card data. Approximately 56% of Crumbs&#146;
    current revenue is attributable to credit card transactions, and
    that percentage is expected to climb. Crumbs&#146; systems could
    be compromised in the future, which could result in the
    misappropriation of customer information or the disruption of
    systems. Either of those consequences could have a material
    adverse effect on Crumbs&#146; reputation and business or
    subject it to additional liabilities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Risks
    Related to the Transaction</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">57th
    Street&#146;s working capital will be reduced to the extent its
    Common Shares and Warrants are tendered in connection with the
    Offer which may cause 57th Street and/or Crumbs to be unable or
    unwilling to consummate the Transaction.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Pursuant to 57th&#160;Street&#146;s Certificate of
    Incorporation, in the event holders of 4,801,544 Common Shares
    or more, tender their Common Shares, 57th&#160;Street will not
    consummate the Transaction. In addition, if the aggregate
    consideration payable as Stock Purchase Price and Warrant
    Purchase Price to tendering holders pursuant to this Offer
    exceeds $9,156,300 the foregoing Cash Condition will not be
    satisfied. The funds released from the Trust&#160;Account to
    57th Street upon consummation of the Transaction will be used to
    pay the $27&#160;million Cash Consideration to the Members in
    accordance with the Business Combination Agreement and the
    liabilities and obligations of 57th Street due and owing or
    incurred at or prior to the Effective Time (i)&#160;to
    stockholders of 57th Street holding Common Shares who shall have
    validly tendered and not properly withdrawn their Common Shares
    and to holders of the outstanding Warrants who shall have
    validly tendered
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    25
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    and not withdrawn their Warrants in the Tender Offer,
    (ii)&#160;to the underwriter of the IPO as to approximately
    $600,193 representing deferred underwriting commissions and
    discounts payable upon consummation of the Merger,
    (iii)&#160;with respect to filings, applications and/ or other
    actions taken pursuant to the Business Combination Agreement
    required under any antitrust laws, and (iv)&#160;to third
    parties (e.g., professionals, advisors, printers, etc.) who have
    rendered services to 57th Street
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    Crumbs in connection with the Merger and the Offer. If the cash
    expected to be available to Crumbs for working capital after the
    consummation of the Merger and the Offer is sufficiently less
    than currently reflected in the cash and cash equivalents line
    of the Pro Forma Combined column entitled &#147;Assuming Maximum
    Allowable Tender of Common Shares and Repurchase of Non-Insider
    Warrants&#148; in the balance sheet included in the Unaudited
    Pro Forma Consolidated Financial Statements, Crumbs may choose
    to exercise its right to terminate the Business Combination
    Agreement that is available to the extent there is a material
    adjustment to the cash portion of the pro forma working capital
    figure in this Offer to Purchase which is attributable to 57th
    Street&#146;s or its subsidiaries&#146; financial condition. If
    the Transaction is consummated and such amount is insufficient
    to fund&#160;Crumbs&#146; working capital requirements, 57th
    Street or Crumbs would need to borrow funds necessary to satisfy
    such requirements following the consummation of the Transaction
    or curtail their plans for store expansion. There is no
    assurance that such funds would be available to 57th Street or
    Crumbs on terms favorable to it or at all.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Concentration
    of ownership after the Merger may have the effect of delaying or
    preventing a change in control.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    If the Transaction is consummated, the Sponsor and the Members
    will own approximately 4.65% and 39.15%, respectively, of the
    combined voting power of 57th Street assuming that none of the
    Common Shares are validly tendered and not properly withdrawn in
    the Offer, none of the outstanding Warrants are exercised, none
    of the Contingency Consideration is issued and no securities are
    issued pursuant to the Incentive Plan. As a result, such
    persons, if acting together, have the ability to influence the
    outcome of corporate actions of 57th Street requiring
    stockholder approval. In addition, during the Earnout Period,
    the Members as the initial holders of the 57th Street
    Series&#160;A Voting Preferred Stock, will be entitled to elect
    a majority of our board of directors. This concentration of
    ownership may have the effect of delaying or preventing a change
    in control and might adversely affect the market price of 57th
    Street&#146;s Securities.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Directors
    of 57th Street have potential conflicts of interest in
    structuring and negotiating the Transaction and approval of the
    other transactions described in this Offer to
    Purchase.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    When considering whether to tender your Common Shares or
    Warrants pursuant to the Offer, 57th&#160;Street securityholders
    should be aware that directors and executive officers of
    57th&#160;Street have interests in the Transaction that may be
    different from, or in addition to, the interests of
    57th&#160;Street securityholders. These interests include:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the continued indemnification of current directors and officers
    of 57th&#160;Street under the Business Combination Agreement and
    the continuation of directors&#146; and officers&#146; liability
    insurance following the consummation of the Transaction;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the retention of some of the directors and officers of
    57th&#160;Street as directors and officers of 57th Street
    following the consummation of the Transaction;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the continued right of the 57th&#160;Street founders to hold
    common stock in 57th&#160;Street following consummation of the
    Transaction.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    These interests may influence the 57th&#160;Street executive
    officers and directors in the negotiation of the Business
    Combination Agreement and the approval of the other transactions
    described in this Offer to Purchase.
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    26
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">57th
    Street&#146;s ability to request indemnification from the
    Members for damages arising out of claims for indemnification
    pursuant to the Business Combination Agreement is limited to
    approximately 16.67% of the Equity Consideration issued in the
    Transaction which will be held in escrow.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    The indemnification obligations of the Members to
    57th&#160;Street against losses that 57th Street may sustain and
    that result from, arise out of or relate to any breach by of any
    of their representations, warranties, or the covenants or
    agreements contained in the Business Combination Agreement
    one-half of the 33.33% of the Equity Consideration placed in
    escrow (with 57th&#160;Street&#146;s transfer agent or another
    independent escrow agent) or an aggregate of 650,000 of the New
    Crumbs Class&#160;B Exchangeable Units (as defined below) and
    65,000&#160;shares of 57th Street Series&#160;A Voting Preferred
    Stock, or at the Members&#146; option, cash. Other than with
    respect to claims of fraud or intentional or willful
    misrepresentation or omission, the approximately 16.67% of the
    shares in escrow will be the sole remedy for 57th&#160;Street
    for its rights to indemnification pursuant to the Business
    Combination Agreement. Claims for indemnification may be
    asserted against the escrow by 57th&#160;Street once its damages
    exceed a $200,000 deductible and will be reimbursable to the
    full extent of the damages in excess of such amount up to a
    maximum of the escrowed Common Shares. Claims for
    indemnification may be asserted until the date 57th Street files
    its Annual Report on
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-K</FONT>
    for the year ending December&#160;31, 2011. As a consequence of
    these limitations, 57th&#160;Street may not be able to be
    entirely compensated for indemnifiable damages that it may
    sustain.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">57th
    Street&#146;s founders, directors and executive officers have
    certain interests in consummating the Merger that may have
    influenced their decision to approve the Business Combination
    Agreement.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Certain of 57th&#160;Street&#146;s founders, directors and
    entities affiliated with certain of its directors and executive
    officers, own Common Shares that were issued prior to
    57th&#160;Street&#146;s IPO in consideration for an aggregate
    purchase price of $25,000. Such purchasers have waived their
    right to receive distributions with respect to the founder
    shares upon 57th&#160;Street&#146;s liquidation which will occur
    if 57th&#160;Street is unable to consummate the Transaction by
    August&#160;19, 2011. Accordingly, the founder shares will be
    worthless if 57th&#160;Street is forced to liquidate. In
    addition, in the event of 57th&#160;Street&#146;s liquidation,
    the 57th&#160;Street Warrants, including the Insider Warrants
    held by certain of 57th&#160;Street&#146;s directors and
    executive officers, will expire worthless. As of the date of
    this Offer to Purchase, 57th&#160;Street&#146;s founders held an
    aggregate of $6,080,747.60 of common stock (based the closing
    price of the common stock on the OTCBB of $10.03 on
    February&#160;18, 2011)&#160;and an aggregate of $4,200,000 of
    Warrants (based the closing price of the Warrants on the OTCBB
    of $1.20 on February&#160;18, 2011). The founders and Sponsor
    have agreed to tender all of the Insider Warrants owned by them.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    Additionally, it is expected that Mark D. Klein, our chairman of
    the board of directors, will resign as chairman and continue as
    a director of 57th Street following the consummation of the
    Transaction. As such, in the future Mr.&#160;Klein will receive
    any cash fees, stock options or stock awards that 57th
    Street&#146;s board of directors determines to pay to its
    non-executive directors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    These financial interests of 57th&#160;Street&#146;s founders,
    officers and directors and entities affiliated with them may
    have influenced their decision to approve the Transaction. You
    should consider these interests when evaluating the Transaction
    and the Offer.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: transparent">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">The
    exercise of discretion by 57th Street&#146;s directors and
    officers in agreeing to changes to the terms of or waivers of
    closing conditions in the Business Combination Agreement or the
    Offer to Purchase may result in a conflict of interest when
    determining whether such changes to the terms of the Business
    Combination Agreement or this Offer to Purchase or waivers of
    conditions are appropriate and in the 57th Street&#146;s
    securityholders&#146; best interest.</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    In the period leading up to the consummation of the Transaction,
    events may occur that, pursuant to the Business Combination
    Agreement, would require 57th&#160;Street to agree to further
    amend the Business Combination Agreement, to consent to certain
    actions taken by Crumbs or the Members or to waive rights that
    57th&#160;Street is entitled to under the Business Combination
    Agreement. Such events could arise because of changes in the
    course of Crumbs&#146; business, a request by Crumbs to
    undertake actions that would otherwise be prohibited by the
    terms of the Business Combination Agreement or the occurrence of
    other events that would
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <BR>
    27
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->
